title: About
text: This is my blog for DS334!

title: Blog Post 3
text:
In this blog post I will be exploring the data set Collegiate sports from the github page tidytuesday, For this post I am interested in exploring the total revenue and expenditure for collegiate sports at a variety of schools. To do this I will use the variables
year, the year the data represents
institution_name, the school
classification_name, the division
classification_code, more information about the division
total_rev_menwomen, total revenue generated by mens and womens sports
total_exp_menwomen, total expenditures for mens and womens sports

title: Blog Post 3
text:
Connection to Class
The fine tuning of these graphs is what I think the class helps with the most, and given these graphs are still very messy the connection to class is not displayed very well. But they are more advanced graphs than I would have been able to do before this class.

title: Blog Post 1
text: My first blog post is in collaboration with Tess Downing and we are exploring the data set “Roy Kent F**k count”.

title: Blog Post 1
text:
Connection to Class
The plot with the most connection to this class is the last one showing the average IMdb rating from each season. The other graphs show connection as well because we would not have been able to clean them up as well without what we’ve learned so for from this class, but the last graph does have the most elevated level of creation.

title: Blog Post 2
text:
In this blog post I’ll be exploring a data set about tornadoes in the United States from 1950 to 2022. This data comes from the data set Tornados. I found the data set on the github repo tidytuesday, and the information posted there came from NOAA’s National Weather Service Storm Prediction Center Severe Weather Maps, Graphics, and Data Page.
For this blog post the variables I’m interested in are
yr, the year it occurred
st, the state(s) it affected
mag, the magnitude on the F scale
loss, the estimated property loss (in dollars)
The first thing I want to investigate how many tornadoes each state recorded from 1950 to 2022, for this I will create a map of the US displaying tornado count in each state.

## Read in data 

library(tidyverse)

tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load('2023-05-16')
tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load(2023, week = 20)

tornados <- tuesdata$tornados
tornados_smaller <- tornados |> select(om, yr, mo, st, mag, loss, ns)

## map of US and tornado
library(maps)
library(tidyverse)
state_df <- ggplot2::map_data("state")
state.abb
state.name

abb_name <- bind_cols(state.abb, state.name) |> rename(abb = `...1`,
                                                       state = `...2`) |>
  mutate(state = str_to_lower(state)) 

library(ggrepel)

title: Blog Post 2
text:
Connection to Class
Building maps like the ones I used is completely thanks to this class and I hope to learn more about creating maps, along with other skills. I feel like the last graph I tried to build is possible with what we’ve learned so far but just couldn’t get it.
